name: ADP
def: The invasion success of non-native species depends on the adaptation to the conditions in the exotic range before and/or after the introduction. Non-native species that are related to native species are more successful in this adaptation
label: Adaptation hypothesis
title:
Hypothesis
Adaptation hypothesis
The invasion success of non-native species depends on the adaptation to the conditions in the exotic range before and/or after the introduction. Non-native species that are related to native species are more successful in this adaptation

name: BA
def: Ecosystems tend to accommodate the establishment and coexistence of non-native species despite the presence and abundance of native species
label: Biotic acceptance hypothesis
title:
Hypothesis
Biotic acceptance hypothesis
Ecosystems tend to accommodate the establishment and coexistence of non-native species despite the presence and abundance of native species

name: BID
def: Non-native species benefit from different indirect effects triggered by native species
label: Biotic indirect effects hypothesis
title:
Hypothesis
Biotic indirect effects hypothesis
Non-native species benefit from different indirect effects triggered by native species

name: BR
def: An ecosystem with high biodiversity is more resistant against non-native species than an ecosystem with lower biodiversity
label: Biotic resistance hypothesis
title:
Hypothesis
Biotic resistance hypothesis
An ecosystem with high biodiversity is more resistant against non-native species than an ecosystem with lower biodiversity

name: CP
def: Colonization pressure is defined as the number of species introduced to a given location. As colonization pressure increases, the number of established or invasive non-native species in that location is predicted to increase
label: Colonization pressure hypothesis
title:
Hypothesis
Colonization pressure hypothesis
Colonization pressure is defined as the number of species introduced to a given location. As colonization pressure increases, the number of established or invasive non-native species in that location is predicted to increase

name: DEM
def: The establishment of a non-native species depends on natural fluctuations of the ecosystem, which influence the level of competition from local species
label: Dynamic equilibrium model hypothesis
title:
Hypothesis
Dynamic equilibrium model hypothesis
The establishment of a non-native species depends on natural fluctuations of the ecosystem, which influence the level of competition from local species

name: DN
def: The invasion success of non-native species is higher in areas that are poor in closely related species than in areas that are rich in closely related species
label: Darwin’s naturalization hypothesis
title:
Hypothesis
Darwin’s naturalization hypothesis
The invasion success of non-native species is higher in areas that are poor in closely related species than in areas that are rich in closely related species

name: DIST
def: The invasion success of non-native species is higher in highly disturbed than in relatively undisturbed ecosystems
label: Disturbance hypothesis
title:
Hypothesis
Disturbance hypothesis
The invasion success of non-native species is higher in highly disturbed than in relatively undisturbed ecosystems

name: EE
def: Introduced enemies of a non-native species are less harmful to the non-native than to the native species
label: Enemy of my enemy hypothesis
title:
Hypothesis
Enemy of my enemy hypothesis
Introduced enemies of a non-native species are less harmful to the non-native than to the native species

name: EI
def: Introduced enemies of non-native species are less harmful for them in the exotic than the native range, due to altered biotic and abiotic conditions
label: Enemy inversion hypothesis
title:
Hypothesis
Enemy inversion hypothesis
Introduced enemies of non-native species are less harmful for them in the exotic than the native range, due to altered biotic and abiotic conditions

name: EICA
full_name: Evolution of increased competitive ability hypothesis
def: After having been released from natural enemies, non-native species will allocate more energy in growth and/or reproduction (this re-allocation is due to genetic changes), which makes them more competitive
label: Evolution of increased competitive ability hypothesis
title:
Hypothesis
Evolution of increased competitive ability hypothesis
After having been released from natural enemies, non-native species will allocate more energy in growth and/or reproduction (this re-allocation is due to genetic changes), which makes them more competitive

name: EIM
def: Invasion patterns are a function of the evolutionary characteristics of both the recipient region and potential donor regions. Species from regions with highly diverse evolutionary lineages are more likely to become successful invaders in less diverse regions
label: Ecological imbalance hypothesis
title:
Hypothesis
Ecological imbalance hypothesis
Invasion patterns are a function of the evolutionary characteristics of both the recipient region and potential donor regions. Species from regions with highly diverse evolutionary lineages are more likely to become successful invaders in less diverse regions

name: EN
def: The invasion success of non-native species increases with the availability of empty niches in the exotic range
label: Empty niche hypothesis
title:
Hypothesis
Empty niche hypothesis
The invasion success of non-native species increases with the availability of empty niches in the exotic range

name: ENA
def: The impact of a non-native species on biodiversity is influenced by the evolutionary experience of the invaded community. Thus, the largest impacts are caused by species (e.g., predators, herbivores, pathogens) invading systems where no phylogenetically or functionally similar species exist
label: Ecological naivety hypothesis
title:
Hypothesis
Ecological naivety hypothesis
The impact of a non-native species on biodiversity is influenced by the evolutionary experience of the invaded community. Thus, the largest impacts are caused by species (e.g., predators, herbivores, pathogens) invading systems where no phylogenetically or functionally similar species exist

name: ER
def: The absence of enemies in the exotic range is a cause of invasion success
label: Enemy release hypothesis
title:
Hypothesis
Enemy release hypothesis
The absence of enemies in the exotic range is a cause of invasion success

name: ERD
def: The partial release of enemies in the exotic range is a cause of invasion success
label: Enemy reduction hypothesis
title:
Hypothesis
Enemy reduction hypothesis
The partial release of enemies in the exotic range is a cause of invasion success

name: EVH
def: The invasion success of non-native species is high if the exotic range has a highly heterogeneous environment
label: Environmental heterogeneity hypothesis
title:
Hypothesis
Environmental heterogeneity hypothesis
The invasion success of non-native species is high if the exotic range has a highly heterogeneous environment

name: GC
def: A large number of different non-native species is more successful than a small number
label: Global competition hypothesis
title:
Hypothesis
Global competition hypothesis
A large number of different non-native species is more successful than a small number

name: HC
def: Species that live in close proximity to humans are more successful in invading new areas than other species.
label: Human commensalism hypothesis
title:
Hypothesis
Human commensalism hypothesis
Species that live in close proximity to humans are more successful in invading new areas than other species.

name: HF
def: The invasion success of non-native species in the new area is high if they are pre-adapted to this area
label: Habitat filtering hypothesis
title:
Hypothesis
Habitat filtering hypothesis
The invasion success of non-native species in the new area is high if they are pre-adapted to this area

name: IM
def: The presence of non-native species in an ecosystem facilitates invasion by additional species, increasing their likelihood of survival or ecological impact
label: Invasional meltdown hypothesis
title:
Hypothesis
Invasional meltdown hypothesis
The presence of non-native species in an ecosystem facilitates invasion by additional species, increasing their likelihood of survival or ecological impact

name: IRA
def: The invasion success of non-native species increases with the availability of resources
label: Increased resource availability hypothesis
title:
Hypothesis
Increased resource availability hypothesis
The invasion success of non-native species increases with the availability of resources

name: IS
def: Non-native species richness increases with urbanization.
label: Invader species hypothesis
title:
Hypothesis
Invader species hypothesis
Non-native species richness increases with urbanization.

name: ISH
def: Non-native species are more likely to become established and have major ecological impacts on islands than on continents
label: Island susceptibility hypothesis
title:
Hypothesis
Island susceptibility hypothesis
Non-native species are more likely to become established and have major ecological impacts on islands than on continents

name: IW
def: The invasion success of a non-native species depends on its specific traits (e.g., life-history traits)
label: Ideal weed hypothesis
title:
Hypothesis
Ideal weed hypothesis
The invasion success of a non-native species depends on its specific traits (e.g., life-history traits)

name: LS
def: The invasion success of non-native species is high if they strongly differ from native species, and low if they are similar to native species
label: Limiting similarity hypothesis
title:
Hypothesis
Limiting similarity hypothesis
The invasion success of non-native species is high if they strongly differ from native species, and low if they are similar to native species

name: MM
def: In their exotic range, non-native species suffer from missing mutualists
label: Missed mutualisms hypothesis
title:
Hypothesis
Missed mutualisms hypothesis
In their exotic range, non-native species suffer from missing mutualists

name: NAS
def: New relationships between non-native and native species can positively or negatively influence the establishment of the non-native species
label: New associations hypothesis
title:
Hypothesis
New associations hypothesis
New relationships between non-native and native species can positively or negatively influence the establishment of the non-native species

name: NW
def: In the exotic range, non-native species can have a competitive advantage against native species because they possess a novel weapon, that is, a trait that is new to the resident community of native species and, therefore, affects them negatively
label: Novel weapons hypothesis
title:
Hypothesis
Novel weapons hypothesis
In the exotic range, non-native species can have a competitive advantage against native species because they possess a novel weapon, that is, a trait that is new to the resident community of native species and, therefore, affects them negatively

name: OW
def: The invasion success of non-native species increases with the availability of empty niches in the exotic range, and the availability of these niches fluctuates spatio-temporally
label: Opportunity windows hypothesis
title:
Hypothesis
Opportunity windows hypothesis
The invasion success of non-native species increases with the availability of empty niches in the exotic range, and the availability of these niches fluctuates spatio-temporally

name: PH
def: Invasive species are more phenotypically plastic than non-invasive or native ones
label: Plasticity hypothesis
title:
Hypothesis
Plasticity hypothesis
Invasive species are more phenotypically plastic than non-invasive or native ones

name: PES
def: Alien arthropods proliferate on "naive" native host Plants.
label: ﻿Pest outbreaks - defense-free space hypothesis
title:
Hypothesis
﻿Pest outbreaks - defense-free space hypothesis
Alien arthropods proliferate on "naive" native host Plants.

name: PP
def: A high propagule pressure (a composite measure consisting of the number of individuals introduced per introduction event and the frequency of introduction events) is a cause of invasion success
label: Propagule pressure hypothesis
title:
Hypothesis
Propagule pressure hypothesis
A high propagule pressure (a composite measure consisting of the number of individuals introduced per introduction event and the frequency of introduction events) is a cause of invasion success

name: RER
def: The non-native species is released from its natural enemies and can spend more energy in its reproduction, and invasion success increases with the availability of resources
label: Resource-enemy release hypothesis
title:
Hypothesis
Resource-enemy release hypothesis
The non-native species is released from its natural enemies and can spend more energy in its reproduction, and invasion success increases with the availability of resources

name: RI
def: A population of a non-native species that is highly successful shortly after its introduction can decline or disappear over time due to different reasons (such as competition with other introduced species or adaptation by native species)
label: Reckless invader aka ‘boom-bust’ hypothesis
title:
Hypothesis
Reckless invader aka ‘boom-bust’ hypothesis
A population of a non-native species that is highly successful shortly after its introduction can decline or disappear over time due to different reasons (such as competition with other introduced species or adaptation by native species)

name: SDH
def: After having been released from natural specialist enemies, non-native species will allocate more energy to cheap (energy-inexpensive) defences against generalist enemies and less energy to expensive defences against specialist enemies (this re-allocation is due to genetic changes); the energy gained in this way will be invested in growth and/or reproduction, which makes the non-native species more competitive
label: Shifting defence hypothesis
title:
Hypothesis
Shifting defence hypothesis
After having been released from natural specialist enemies, non-native species will allocate more energy to cheap (energy-inexpensive) defences against generalist enemies and less energy to expensive defences against specialist enemies (this re-allocation is due to genetic changes); the energy gained in this way will be invested in growth and/or reproduction, which makes the non-native species more competitive

name: SG
def: Non-native species are more successful in a new region if the local predators are specialists and local mutualists are generalists
label: Specialist-generalist hypothesis
title:
Hypothesis
Specialist-generalist hypothesis
Non-native species are more successful in a new region if the local predators are specialists and local mutualists are generalists

name: SP
def: A large number of different non-native species is more likely to become invasive than a small number due to interspecific competition. Also, the species identity of the locals is more important than the richness in terms of the invasion of an area
label: Sampling hypothesis
title:
Hypothesis
Sampling hypothesis
A large number of different non-native species is more likely to become invasive than a small number due to interspecific competition. Also, the species identity of the locals is more important than the richness in terms of the invasion of an area

name: TEN
def: Approximately 10% of species successfully take consecutive steps of the invasion process
label: Tens rule
title:
Hypothesis
Tens rule
Approximately 10% of species successfully take consecutive steps of the invasion process
